title: Wednesday, 17th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE

Hi. Welcome, Hello. This is Markets Live.

BE

And for today's portrait, it's a welcome return for Mr Dial A Dog.

BE

11:05 am
BE

Who's right now likely to be in his office on the 35th Floor of Heron Tower

BE

Though probably not in his Donald Duck waistcoat

BE

Powa Technologies, one of the UK’s most highly valued technology start-ups, held back staff salaries and payments to suppliers as the company struggled to secure new investment.

In a video message to staff late last year that has been seen by the Financial Times, Dan Wagner, founder and chief executive of the mobile commerce group, said that the company was “missing or late with staff payments and salaries”.

He added that the company had held back payments to “all of our suppliers” and some staff were locked out of offices “across Europe as we’ve held up payments to people like Regus”, the serviced office company.

11:06 am
BE

http://www.ft.com/...-8564e7528e54.html

BE

Mr Wagner has predicted that the business will be bigger than Google or Alibaba, the Chinese ecommerce group. “What we’re building here is the biggest tech company in living memory,” he told the Financial Times in April last year.

But in the video to staff, Mr Wagner said that the company was “basically pre-revenue”, a term that refers to a lack of sales. “As we go forward from here that revenue will start to flow in meaningful ways but right now it isn’t,” he said.

BE

So what is PowaTag, you ask?

11:08 am
BE

Well, it's a QR code reader.

BE

Attached to a payment system.

BE

There are a hundred thousand million partners, of course, because that's the way of Danterprises.

11:08 am
BE

But the only proof of concept appears to be at Twickenham stadium.

BE
BE

See? QR codes. It's a breakthrough.

11:09 am
BE

And there's such an appetite for QR code readers that they've had to bribe potential customers with free booze.

BE

http://taguk.powa.com/cart?sku=1111MBDM

BE

So while it's pre revenue, it's very much not pre cost.

11:11 am
BE

(@Mo: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QR_code )

BE

(Or if you prefer, here's the Pictures of People Scanning QR Codes blog: http://picturesofp...rcodes.tumblr.com/ )

undefined
11:13 am
BE

So anyway, day four.

BE

FTSE up 1.6% at pixel, threatening to go back above 6k

BE

That's a 7% rally or thereabouts in four sessions.

11:14 am
BE

Why? Dunno. Nor does anyone else.

BE

In terms of the movers, we have Glencore.

BE

Going early to refinance its RCF.

11:15 am
BE

(That means revolving credit facility, in case anyone's confused. I'd not like another QR code outrage.)

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 113.41, up 10.46 (+10.16%), High: 115.00, Low: 105.00, Volume: 61.11m
BE

Caz incoming.

11:17 am
BE

Glencore has announced that it has refinanced its $8.5bn core revolving
credit facility. This is 3 months earlier than it typically refinances this
facility and will send a powerful signal to equity markets. Importantly, the
RCF remains unsecured, has no financial covenants and has 2 one year
extension options; as such, it retains similar terms to the existing facility.
Syndication was oversubscribed by $3bn showing strong demand for
GLEN debt and vindication of its creditworthiness. At the company’s
discretion, the facility has been reduced to $7.7bn. Pricing has not
disclosed but indicated to be likely smaller than 100bps all in (inclusive of LIBOR
0.43%, margin and commitment fees), which we regard as an impressive
outcome. The refinancing extends GLEN refinancing risk to minimum
2018.

BE

 Company reports FY’15 financials on 1st March: We forecast
$1.81bn FY’15 underlying earnings (USc14/sh), -58% y/y. In-line with
management guidance at its Investor Day in Dec’15 we expect no final
dividend will be declared.
 Positive cash flow status in 2016 and progress on debt reduction: In
Dec’15 GLEN guided to ~$25bn net debt at YE’15 and that it will
generate $2.3bn of FCF in 2016 pre-working capital. At current
commodity prices we calculate $2.4bn of FCF, or $5.7bn after adjusting
for a forecast $3.3bn working capital release. Consequently we forecast
net debt falls to $18.6bn at YE’16, which includes $500m of proceeds
from the streaming transaction at Antapaccay and an assumed 25% sale
of the Ag business for ~$2bn in H2. This puts GLEN on a spot FCF yield
of 27% in 2016E and a sustainable ND / EBITDA of ~2.5x (ex RMI) by
YE’16E.
 Investment thesis remains intact: We upgraded GLEN to OW in
Dec’15, citing exaggerated concerns for its balance sheet and we expect
GLEN’s equity will re-rate as credit risk premiums recede. We highlight
GLEN’s CDS peaked at 1,165bps on 20th Jan and have since fallen to
827bps, whilst over this period its share price has rallied ~45%.
Furthermore, GLEN is attractively valued, in our view, on mark-tomarket 6.5x/7.3x EV/EBITDA vs. peers 7.6x/7.5x and robust FCF yield
of 27%/11% in 2016/17E.

BE

And Deutsche.

11:19 am
BE

Ticking the boxes- next is YE15 net debt and asset sales
Glencore continues to deliver on the plan to address its balance sheet laid out
in September last year. The refinancing of the RCF was expected, but the
consequences of not refinancing would have been material. Glencore
continues to deliver on what is required to get its net debt down to ~$20bn by
YE16. Following the production report last week, focus at the results on March
1 st will be on net debt (DB YE$25.7bn) and marketing EBIT (DBe $2.5bn). On
the asset disposal front the focus is on the Agri assets and the potential copper
assets sales (Lomas Bayas and Cobar), progress on which is expected in 1H16.
Maintain Buy 125p price target
Our Buy recommendation on Glencore is based on its deep discount to NPV
(0.5x) which we believe has been driven by market misunderstanding of the
mechanics of the Glencore balance sheet. We expect management to continue
delivering on its debt management efforts, providing ongoing catalysts for the
shares to re-rate. Our PT is based on a 0.7x NPV multiple in-line with its
relative market sector performance.

BE

Elsewhere, miners are up because everything is.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 425.30, up 27.35 (+6.87%), High: 425.85, Low: 395.65, Volume: 7.05m
11:20 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 715.78, up 22.78 (+3.29%), High: 717.30, Low: 691.10, Volume: 3.78m
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 1,914, up 61.5 (+3.32%), High: 1,924, Low: 1,854, Volume: 2.12m
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 453.30, up 12.7 (+2.88%), High: 456.70, Low: 434.60, Volume: 1.72m
11:21 am
undefined
BE

So it's still half term, which means volume's light, as is news today.

BE

We also have system problems, which is slowing down the session.

11:22 am
BE

If there's anything you think we should be covering, do say.

BE

(@Pseudonym: I'd suggest the main cost, if you're Uber, is lobbying.)

BE

(@Boncoeur: not market makers. But most of the buyside appears to be in Chamonix.)

11:24 am
BE

And, yes, sorry if the system's acting borky.

BE

It is for us too. We don't have a reason why it's gone borky again, though we have plenty of people being copied into the emails to discuss the fact that we don't have a reason.

undefined
11:25 am
BE

Plus500? Sure.

Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 529.41, up 19.41 (+3.81%), High: 552.00, Low: 510.00, Volume: 1.04m
BE

The air cover provided by the Playtech bid has given them time to make things look a bit better

11:27 am
BE

And while all the questions about the business remain unanswered -- such as where are its customers, actually .....

BE

....... the numbers look okay.

BE

Revenue up 2%, customers down 18%.

11:29 am
BE

..... market volatility attracting both strong revenues and new customers with an improved EBITDA margin.

BE

board expects to achieve growth ahead of market expectations for the year as a whole.

BE

"Market expectations" being, I guess, those set by Liberum a week or so ago when it restarted coverage.

11:30 am
BE

As of today, Liberum doesn't really say much.

BE

(PLUS LN) All metrics are very strong. EBITDA of $132.9m is 11% ahead of Libf, Adj. PBT is 10% ahead and EPS of 84 cents is 12% ahead. Ord DPS of 50.43 is 13% ahead of our forecast and including a Special of 33.62 cents it equals a 100% payout. New CEO (Asaf Elimelech) to replace Gal Haber in April'16. Gal to move to MD.
Outlook: very positive statement, highlighting a good start to the new year. Looks like forecasts for 2016 will have to be revised upwards. Reiterate the Buy.

BE

The other brokers look at Plus as a proxy for Playtech.

11:31 am
Playtech PLC (PTEC:LSE): Last: 764.50, up 16.5 (+2.21%), High: 764.50, Low: 750.50, Volume: 321.96k
BE

Which is getting a push from Canaccord, among others.

BE

FT Alphaville's daily live markets thing.

11:32 am
BE

We expect Playtech to finish FY15 with €674m of net cash (treating the €297m convertible bonds as equity, not debt), with an additional €220m in liquid investments (stakes in Ladbrokes and Plus500); it could therefore invest around €1.7bn without incurring leverage of more than 2x Ebitda. We expect management to confirm active M&A discussions, and to commit to a return of cash to shareholders by the year end if it has failed to secure any material investments. The latest target to be the subject of press speculation is Openbet, the sportsbook technology business owned by Vitruvian, which would offer a strong strategic fit for Playtech, and is speculated to be on the market for £250m to £300m (or 16x to 20x FY14 Ebitda).

Playtech paid a £100m special dividend back in 2013, so it has a track record of returning surplus cash to shareholders. But its preference is clearly to invest; and we think an Openbet deal would appeal to investors, given the opportunity to build a significant platform across all key verticals, with material cross-selling opportunities.

BE

Playtech is attractively positioned as a broad-based technology business, focused on a structural growth market. Its B2B model provides diversified risk, and its push into online Financial Trading (via the Trade FX deal) has provided an adjacent growth market.

Valuation

PTEC shares have been hit hard in the recent market sell-off, and trade 20% below their 2015 high, and broadly flat over one year. It is on a 2017F PER of 12.6x (and EV/Ebitda of 8.6x), but strip out cash and the PER falls to just 9.7x, a material discount to even land-based operators like Ladbrokes and William Hill. Exposure to regulated markets is rising, and its strong balance sheet provides significant scope for value enhancing acquisitions, which should drive upgrades. We retain our 1000p TP based on a cash adjusted FY17E PER multiple of 14.0x, and EV/Ebitda of 12.0x. BUY.

BE

There are also very specific reasons not to own Playtech, but let's not damp the mood with those.

11:32 am
undefined
BE

Though that reminds me .........

BE

I was checking David Lenigas's Twitter this morning on the momentous news that Horse **** has filled up two tankers.

11:34 am
BE

(@roddy1234: that feels unnecessary. We're on email.)

BE

And unsurprisingly, there's about 12 pages of crowing and pictures of JR from Dallas.

BE

But there's also this.

11:35 am
BE

https://twitter.com/DavidLenigas/status/699263097727512576

BE

So save you the click, here's the upshot of that petition.

BE

We believe the current system works against the private investor as buys are shown as sells and vise versa according to the ask and bid price set by the market makers at the time of trading. We believe this is wide open to manipulation and misinterprets the facts.

We would like to see a new, fair system that will report a trade factually. In turn this will lead to greater transparency on the London Stock Exchanges.

AIM in particular seems manipulated by the Market Makers.
Actually defeating their roll of creating a real and fair market for investors.

Altering spreads to hide the status of transactions isn't transparent.

11:36 am
BE

Um?

BE

That's not how the LSE works, is it?

BE

There's SETS, which uses an order book, and SETSqx, which is market made but with four clearing auctions a day that use an order book.

11:37 am
BE

Below that is SEAQ, which is entirely market made and is for illiquid stocks.

BE

Trades there will be across a buy-sell spread, and reported as such.

BE

buys are not "shown as sells and vise versa"

11:38 am
BE

(Sic)

BE

Because the LSE doesn't report trades as buys and sells. Only ADVFN and suchlike do that, based on the spread price.

BE

Now, I've no issue with nutso petitions for whatever nonsense happens to be inhabiting someone's head at any given time.

11:40 am
BE

But I'm surprised to see Mr Lenigas, a former director of approximately seventeen-thousand Aim-listed companies, endorse said nonsense.

undefined
BE

Actually, on Horse ****, here's Shore.

11:42 am
BE

Shop broker to Solo Oil.

Solo Oil PLC (SOLO:LSE): Last: 0.33, up 0.02 (+6.45%), High: 0.33, Low: 0.32, Volume: 40.93m
BE

SOLO OIL+ (SOLO, 0.31p, House Stock) – Horse Hill flow testing update. Solo has announced that, following a similar release by operator Horse Hill Developments Limited, that light dry oil has continued to flow naturally at a stabilised rate of over 450bopd from the Lower Kimmeridge interval (during a second day of testing of the Horse Hill-1 well). Flow testing was performed for a total of 9½ hours yesterday; produced oil has been sent by tanker to be refined. With the initial flow rate having been maintained at over 450bopd for a second day, we remain highly encouraged by flow test results from the Lower Kimmeridge zone and, with two further intervals yet to be tested, look forward to further news in the coming days.

11:43 am
BE

Meanwhile, via Malcy .....

BE

Down at Gatwick airport the authorities are on standby as apparently there is so much oil in the area they will only need a local refinery to service the requirements of the airlines. The Gatwick gusher as it has romantically been named, has flowed oil for several hours and it wouldnt surprise me if the Venezuelan minister didnt pop by on his way home to try and persuade the owners to keep production down and not ruin his Doha accord by pumping millions of barrels a day into the world market…

BE

Hm.

11:44 am
BE

We really need to consider the possibility of Gatwick becoming a breakaway state

BE

There's an international airport and an oil field so porous, you basically just need to put a fork in the ground.

undefined
11:47 am
BE

FTSE at 5956 live.

BE

And I'm struggling to find much more to say. Everything's up.

BE

There's Electrocomponents, I guess, in case you're interested in widgets.

11:49 am
Electrocomponents PLC (ECM:LSE): Last: 225.00, up 15.5 (+7.40%), High: 225.60, Low: 214.30, Volume: 947.73k
BE

HSBC turning positive.

BE

What’s in the price? Some believe that current margin pressure is structural, and is
being eroded by online models, the barriers to entry are breached. The current share
prices of Premier Farnell (PFL) & Electrocomponents (ECM) reflect investors’
concerns of weak trading, slowdown in China, and weak EM currencies, as well as a
deep concern that margins are under structural and sustained pressure.
Our view: We believe recent margin pressure has much to do with the fact that these
companies are exposed to a stronger dollar and weaker EM currencies. Both
companies’ margin stabilisation and cost reduction plans look comprehensive. They
may alleviate fears of further profit risk. We are not convinced by internet models, like
Amazon, which targets business areas with 2.5x inventory turn. However, the weak
trading environment will continue to take a toll in the short run. We are not assuming
recession, and would have to cut estimates if we did, but even with weak trading we
see value. Relatively, PFL looks cheap: PFL is currently trading at a 50% discount
to ECM on a FY2 PE multiple compared with a historical discount of 20%. The
market is assigning a higher margin risk to PFL. The company has been without a
permanent CEO since August 14th 2015, the market is concerned that it is taking so
long to find a CEO prepared to take the role. A relatively cheaper valuation makes us
prefer PFL

11:50 am
BE

aluation and target prices: We cut our fair value target price for PFL to 145p (from
155p) by applying FY2 PE multiple of 11x (earlier 13x) on CY17e. But we reiterate
our Buy rating for the stock on valuation grounds. For ECM, we lift our fair value
target price to 250p (from 205p) by applying a PE multiple of 16x (unchanged) on
CY17e and upgrade our rating to Buy (from Hold).

BE

The ECM-Premier merger story hasn't done the rounds for a few months.

BE

Last had a good run when GO Investment Partners appeared on Premier's shareholder list.

11:51 am
BE

Which I think was last May.

BE

They're still in there, right? 5.5 per cent stake

undefined
11:54 am
BE

Cor, what a rubbish day for corporate news. Should we wind up with some strategy?

BE

Because there are a couple of things around worth noting.

BE

Liberum has a recession playbook out.

11:55 am
BE

Not the ideal day for it, but still ......

BE

The probability of an imminent UK recession has almost
certainly risen in the last 6 months. We present ideas for the
‘bear-case’. In part 1, we analyse sector EPS and price
performance during the ’08-09 crisis. We note considerable
overshoot at the Defensives. There is also evidence of a
tradable rotation out of early-cycle sectors first. We would
watch ‘Ultra-Cyclical’ earnings (Banks, Fins, Real Estate,
Housebuilders) for confirmation of a slowdown. In terms of
what to buy now, we see structural growth opportunities at
A&D, Support Services & Healthcare. In part 2 we screen
for stocks where recession risks are not fully priced in (and
the reverse), accompanied by analyst commentary. Finally,
we conclude that Value could cheapen a further 50% vs.
Growth and re-iterate buy strong B/S and safe yield.

BE

I can't grab the charts immediately, so you'll have to do with the words alone.

11:56 am
BE

• Considerable overshoot at the Defensives – The degree of de-rating at
sectors that ultimately saw small earnings downgrades is striking, if
unsurprising. Clearly this can be justified by higher risk premia across all
equities, but arguably still represents a ‘mispricing’ given risk of long-term
capital loss is ostensibly lower. In any case, Defensives were the best
through-cycle performers & also began rallying off the lows first.
• Support Services, Media & Leisure surprisingly defensive – At Support
Services, whilst Recruiters were heavily downgraded, EPS fell

BE

Which is based on median peak-to-trough falls in sector 12m fwd EPS & Price during 2008/9

BE

.... less than 15% for
Constultants and Contractors. Admittedly, there may be a hidden benefit
from robust Energy markets. At Media, Publisher S/Ps fell 50-80%, but
EPS was very resilient (down less than 20%). Broadcasters did suffer however. At
Leisure, Pub & Restaurant stocks appear to have been excessively derated. We think they are more defensive than often believed.

11:58 am
BE

So .........

BE

• Watch Financials and Property related sectors: the 'Ultra-Cyclicals’ –
We think the analysis identifies sectors where KPIs respond most quickly
to aggregate demand in the economy. Starting from the top of the legend
and working downward (they are chronologically sorted by EPS peak), we
notice that contract length and earnings visibility increases (and these are
only the cyclical sectors). Speaking to our Capital Goods team for
example, we hear that a number of companies were saying, as late as
October 2008 “recession, what recession”, only to slash numbers in a
December 2008 IMS.
This gives us fresh evidence that the sectors highest up in the list provide
the best clues as to economic direction, or at least the 1 st and 2nd
derivative. In our view, the probability of a recession would increase
considerably should we start to see downgrades here.
• The market appears further ahead of ‘Ultra-Cyclical’ downgrades this
time (assuming they come), perhaps indicating it is oversold – Above we
argue that the early cycle sectors give a higher 'frequency' indication as to
the state of the economy. Currently, it appears the market is much further
ahead of the fundamentals than at a comparable time in 2008. When the
FTSE 250 was down 15% from peak in the prior-cycle, we had begun to
see real downgrades at the ‘Ultra-Cyclicals’. At present, there is scant 'real
world confirmation' that would validate sell-off, perhaps indicating the
market is oversold (or just more efficient).

BE

There's a lot of quant further in, none of which I can share easily.

12:01 pm
BE

Actually, I can't really share anything easily because the system's rejecting every other message.

BE

(@Whatsgoinngonhelp: nothing to add on what's already written.)

BE

Let's close. I'm done raging at the machine for another day.

12:03 pm
BE

Thanks, ROTR. You've been great in spite of everything. See you tomorrow.

BE

Playtech reports its FY15 results on February 25th and we expect another year of premium underlying growth and strong operational performance. Genuine underlying revenue growth in FY15 of around 15% will be well ahead of its peers, albeit flattered by the impact of low/no margin UK white label contracts. And we expect Ebitda to come in ahead of our projected €245.1m (consensus €247m), representing over 19% growth.

The key focus will be growth rates going into FY16 and guidance on plans for its burgeoning cash pile. Underlying growth should moderate as it has now lapped the launch of white label contracts in H2 FY14; but we still project Q1 growth at 8-10%, with margins benefiting as the white label business hit break-even by the end of H1 (losses of c.€4m in H1 FY15). The Sun contract (around €50m of annualised revenues) kicks in in Q4 and should help drive up scale/margins. A stronger € will create some FX headwinds, but we are comfortable these can be absorbed within existing forecasts.
